items.content_html:
C++20's std::string and std::vector can be marked as constexpr, allowing them to be used in compile-time programming. However, there are two constraints on constexprness: the value cannot depend on runtime input, and certain data cannot flow from compile-time into runtime. The article explains these constraints using examples of stack variables and memory addresses. It also discusses the limitations of constexpr string and vector, such as the inability to escape pointers to their data and the impact of small string optimization (SSO). The intended use of constexpr string and vector is as local variables or return types of constexpr or consteval functions, rather than as constexpr or constinit variables.

31 Points | 10 comments
items.title: Just how constexpr is C++20’s std:string? (quuxplusone.github.io)
items.summary: Understanding the constexprness of C++20's std::string

items.content_html:
CVE-2023-4809: FreeBSD pf bypass vulnerability allows attackers to bypass rules in pf-based IPv6 firewalls. The vulnerability occurs when a non-compliant IPv6 atomic fragment is sent, containing multiple IPv6 fragmentation headers. FreeBSD handles these fragments by rebuilding the original packet but fails to apply any rules that apply to layers four and higher. As a result, the fragment bypasses the firewall and establishes two-way communication between the attacker and the victim. The vulnerability affects all FreeBSD versions up to 13.2-STABLE and 12.4-STABLE. The solution is to update FreeBSD to the latest version.

29 Points | 10 comments
items.title: CVE-2023-4809: FreeBSD pf bypass when using IPv6 (www.enricobassetti.it)
items.summary: CVE-2023-4809: FreeBSD pf Bypass Vulnerability in IPv6 Firewalls

items.content_html:
Aardvark'd: The Fog Creek Documentary, 18 Years Later is a documentary film about Fog Creek's summer internship program in 2005. The film captures interviews with individuals who would go on to achieve fame and success in the tech industry. It explores the indie software scene of 2005, featuring Fog Creek Software, Y Combinator, and the launch of reddit. The documentary showcases the vulnerability and uncertainty experienced by tech startup founders during their early days. Despite its flaws, Aardvark'd provides a relatable and engaging look into the challenges of launching a software product. The film ends without a clear resolution, leaving viewers wondering about the outcome of the interns' project. The documentary includes insightful quotes from Paul Graham and Aaron Swartz. Surprisingly, Fog Creek did not finance the film, and the filmmaker recently uploaded it for free on YouTube.

246 Points | 76 comments
items.title: Aardvark'd: The Fog Creek documentary, 18 years later (mtlynch.io)
items.summary: Aardvark'd: The Fog Creek Documentary, 18 Years Later - A Look into the Early Days of Tech Startup Founders

The release notes highlight various bug fixes and improvements, including fixes for sourcemaps, hot reloading, module imports, debugger support, and more. The release also brings in uSockets and uWebSockets forks into Bun's repository. The changelog lists all the changes made from version 0.8.1 to 1.0.0. items.content_html:
Zinc-air batteries have been identified as a cheaper and safer alternative to lithium-ion batteries for powering electric vehicles, according to a study by Edith Cowan University. The research found that zinc-air batteries, which use a combination of sustainable and cost-effective materials, offer improved lifespan and performance compared to lithium-ion batteries. The breakthrough design of these batteries, using new materials such as carbon, iron, and cobalt, has overcome previous limitations related to power output and lifespan. The use of abundant zinc resources in countries like Australia, along with the ubiquity of air, makes zinc-air batteries a viable and reliable energy storage solution. This development contributes to building a sustainable society and reducing reliance on fossil fuels.

70 Points | 59 comments
items.title: Zinc-air batteries as an alternative to lithium-ion: study (www.ecu.edu.au)
items.summary: Zinc-air batteries identified as cheaper and safer alternative to lithium-ion batteries

items.content_html:
The article discusses the challenges and delays in developing a malaria vaccine. It highlights the complexity of the malaria parasite and the lack of financial incentive and urgency as major obstacles. The discovery of the malaria parasite by Charles Laveran in 1880 is mentioned, along with the difficulties in finding a suitable animal model for vaccine development. The article also introduces the concept of Advance Market Commitments as a potential solution to encourage investment in vaccines for diseases affecting the global poor. Overall, the article emphasizes the need for innovative approaches to accelerate the development of vaccines for diseases like malaria.

50 Points | 25 comments
items.title: Why we didn’t get a malaria vaccine sooner (worksinprogress.co)
items.summary: The Challenges and Delays in Developing a Malaria Vaccine

items.content_html:
Safety Inspector Fired For Finding 'Too Many Defects' Could Cost Railroad Millions. Former track inspector Don Sanders reveals a culture of ignoring safety in favor of profit at Burlington Northern Santa Fe (BNSF). Sanders had previously sued BNSF in 2017 for retaliation after reporting numerous defects. BNSF has a history of destroying evidence and retaliating against employees. Secretly recorded phone calls from the lawsuit expose BNSF's disregard for safety, with employees questioning why defects aren't fixed and supervisors discouraging calls to the Federal Railroad Administration. Other track inspectors confirm the pressure to overlook defects and the consequences of reporting them. Despite the evidence, Sanders' supervisor still has his job, received a raise, and a bonus.

10 Points | 0 comments
items.title: Safety Inspector Fired for Finding Too Many Defects Could Cost Railroad Millions (jalopnik.com)
items.summary: Safety Inspector Fired For Finding 'Too Many Defects' Exposes Culture of Ignoring Safety at Railroad Company

items.content_html:
The paper introduces Optimization by PROmpting (OPRO), a method that leverages large language models (LLMs) as optimizers. OPRO uses natural language prompts to generate new solutions in each optimization step. The authors demonstrate the effectiveness of OPRO on linear regression, traveling salesman problems, and prompt optimization tasks. They show that prompts optimized by OPRO outperform human-designed prompts by up to 8% on GSM8K and by up to 50% on Big-Bench Hard tasks. The paper falls under the categories of Machine Learning, Artificial Intelligence, and Computation and Language.

65 Points | 20 comments
items.title: Large Language Models as Optimizers. +50% on Big Bench Hard (arxiv.org)
items.summary: Leveraging Large Language Models as Optimizers: Introducing Optimization by PROmpting (OPRO)

Together Computer Inc's privacy policy outlines the collection, use, and sharing of personal data through their model training and inference platform. The policy applies to data collected through the services, training algorithms, company websites, and third-party sources. It does not cover personal data of company employees and candidates. The policy highlights the types of data collected, such as user names, IP addresses, and contact information, and explains how the company uses this data for purposes like improving the service and contacting users. It also discusses data retention, transfer, and security measures. The policy includes supplemental terms and conditions for regions like Europe and California.

25 Points | 10 comments
items.title: Llama 2 on togetherAI is as bad of a privacy nightmare as OpenAI (together.ai)
items.summary: Together Computer Inc Privacy Policy: Collection, Use, and Sharing of Personal Data

items.content_html:
Artie is seeking a Founding Engineer to join their small team in San Francisco. The role involves working on distributed systems and data engineering, with responsibilities including setting up new data planes, optimizing their open-sourced service product, and adding functionality to the customer dashboard. The ideal candidate should have strong fundamentals in computer science, be pragmatic, and have experience with scaling asynchronous systems. Proficiency in Go is preferred. Artie is a real-time data streaming solution that focuses on databases and data warehouses, utilizing change data capture and stream processing for efficient data transfers with sub-minute latency.

1 Points | 0 comments
items.title: Artie (YC S23) is hiring a founding engineer (www.ycombinator.com)
items.summary: Artie Seeks Founding Engineer for Real-Time Data Streaming Solution

items.content_html:
Researchers at the University of California San Diego have discovered security flaws in the email forwarding process that allow scammers to impersonate high-profile domains. This vulnerability affects tens of thousands of domains, including government organizations, financial service companies, and major news organizations. The researchers found that scammers can send spoofed emails that bypass the safeguards of email providers like Gmail and Outlook, increasing the likelihood of recipients opening malicious attachments or clicking on harmful links. The vulnerabilities arise from the delegation of email infrastructure to third-party providers and the assumption that each organization operates its own mailing infrastructure. While some providers have patched the issues, the researchers recommend disabling open forwarding and implementing stricter validation policies to address the root problem.

3 Points | 0 comments
items.title: Scammers Can Exploit Email Forwarding Flaws to Impersonate High-Profile Domains (today.ucsd.edu)
items.summary: Security Flaws in Email Forwarding Allow Scammers to Impersonate High-profile Domains

items.content_html:
The article discusses the challenges and limitations of using async Rust for concurrency. It explains the difference between parallelism and concurrency and how breaking a problem into separate, independent parts can improve performance. The author explores the use of threads and mutex-based concurrency, highlighting the drawbacks and complexities involved. They then introduce the concept of channels as a synchronization mechanism and discuss how many modern languages, including Rust, provide channels in their standard libraries. The article also delves into the unique challenges of async Rust, such as the need to assure the compiler of data safety and the limitations of using Arc for dynamic lifetimes. Overall, the author suggests that while Rust may not be the best tool for massively concurrent, userspace software, it can still be valuable for other projects.

332 Points | 269 comments
items.title: Maybe Rust isn’t a good tool for massively concurrent, userspace software (bitbashing.io)
items.summary: Challenges and Limitations of Async Rust for Concurrency

items.content_html:
Air pollution degrades the scent of flowers, making it difficult for bees to find them, according to a study by the UK Centre for Ecology & Hydrology and several universities. The research found that ground-level ozone, formed when nitrogen oxide emissions react with volatile organic compounds, changes the size and scent of floral odour plumes. This reduced honeybees' ability to recognise odours by up to 90% from just a few metres away. The study suggests that ozone could have a negative impact on wildflower abundance and crop yields, with implications for food security. The research highlights the need to take action on air pollution to protect pollinators and preserve biodiversity.

121 Points | 24 comments
items.title: Bees struggle to find flowers because of air pollution (www.birmingham.ac.uk)
items.summary: Air pollution degrades floral scent, making it difficult for bees to find flowers

Robin Sloan announces the upcoming publication of his new novel in June 2024 and shares his excitement. He discusses the influence of fantasy sagas on his previous novels and explores the idea of going beyond homage to actively participate in the genre. Sloan plans to create a rich introduction and companion for his new novel, incorporating various influences and media. He also reviews a novel by Michiko Aoyama and reflects on the need for creative investigations of decency and goodness. Sloan asks for nominations of great author websites and discusses the problem-solving power of walking. He concludes by highlighting the quality of science journalism and sharing an interesting logo treatment for Mattel Electronics.

items.content_html:
FTC judge rules that Intuit's 'free' TurboTax ads were misleading, finding that the company deceived consumers by advertising its tax filing service as free when users had to pay to use it. The ruling includes evidence of commercials and online ads promoting the 'Free Edition' software. Intuit was also criticized for making its actually free Free File version difficult to find. The judge issued a cease-and-desist order, prohibiting Intuit from engaging in deceptive practices and requiring clear disclosure of any terms that would limit offers. Intuit responded by calling the investigation process flawed and questionable, stating that it already adheres to most advertising practices in the FTC's decision. The IRS is working on a government-backed free filing service for the 2024 tax season.

189 Points | 36 comments
items.title: FTC judge decides Intuit’s ‘free’ TurboTax ads misled consumers (www.theverge.com)
items.summary: FTC Judge Finds Intuit's 'Free' TurboTax Ads Misled Consumers

items.content_html:
ASMesh is a new protocol that provides anonymous and secure messaging in mesh networks. It addresses the limitations of centralized service providers in scenarios like mass protests in censored networks. The protocol is designed to achieve forward and post-compromise security, as well as forward and post-compromise anonymity. It builds on Signal's Double Ratchet protocol and introduces enhancements to ensure strong confidentiality and anonymity under user corruptions. The protocol's security is proven and its performance is evaluated in simulated mesh networks. The paper also includes a proof of concept implementation.

5 Points | 0 comments
items.title: ASMesh: Anonymous, Secure Messaging in Mesh Networks (eprint.iacr.org)
items.summary: ASMesh: Anonymous and Secure Messaging in Mesh Networks Using Stronger, Anonymous Double Ratchet

items.content_html:
Rivet is a visual programming environment for building AI agents with LLMs. It allows teams to design, debug, and collaborate on complex LLM prompt graphs and deploy them in their own environment. The tool offers features like visualizing and building complex chains, remote debugging, and collaboration through versioning in a team's repository. Rivet has received positive feedback from users who appreciate its visual nature, debugging capabilities, and collaborative features. It has been used by Ironclad to develop their virtual contract assistant, Contract AI. Developers can easily get started with Rivet by following the provided guide and integrating it into their applications.

107 Points | 26 comments
items.title: Show HN: Rivet – open-source AI Agent dev env with real-world applications (rivet.ironcladapp.com)
items.summary: Rivet: A Visual Programming Environment for Building AI Agents with LLMs

items.content_html:
Apple is reportedly investing millions of dollars per day into artificial intelligence, with multiple AI models being developed across different teams. The company's conversational AI unit, called 'Foundational Models,' is led by John Giannandrea and is working on chatbots and automating tasks with Siri. Other teams are focused on image generation and multimodal AI. Apple's most advanced language model, Ajax GPT, has been trained on over 200 billion parameters and is believed to be more powerful than OpenAI's GPT-3.5. The model is currently used internally and Apple has not commented on the report.

22 Points | 8 comments
items.title: Apple is reportedly spending ‘millions of dollars a day’ training AI (www.theverge.com)
items.summary: Apple Reportedly Investing Millions in AI Training, Believes Ajax Model is More Powerful than ChatGPT

items.content_html:
Apple issues update to fix zero-click vulnerability exploited by NSO Group's Pegasus spyware. The exploit chain, known as BLASTPASS, targeted iPhones running the latest iOS version without user interaction. Citizen Lab discovered and disclosed the vulnerability to Apple, who issued two CVEs related to the exploit. Users are urged to update their devices immediately and consider enabling Lockdown Mode for added protection. The incident highlights the ongoing targeting of civil society organizations by sophisticated cyber threats. Apple's response and collaboration with Citizen Lab are commended.

1316 Points | 725 comments
items.title: NSO group iPhone zero-click, zero-day exploit captured in the wild (citizenlab.ca)
items.summary: Apple Releases Update to Address Zero-Click Vulnerability Exploited by NSO Group's Pegasus Spyware

items.content_html:
Specialized astrocytes in the central nervous system mediate glutamatergic gliotransmission, playing a role in brain circuitry assembly and function. Through the use of molecular, bioinformatic, and imaging approaches, researchers identified a subpopulation of astrocytes in the hippocampus that selectively expressed synaptic-like glutamate-release machinery. These astrocytes were found to respond to astrocyte-selective stimulations with subsecond glutamate release events at specific locations. Deletion of the vesicular glutamate transporter 1 (VGLUT1) in these astrocytes suppressed the glutamate release. The study provides insights into the complex roles of astrocytes in the central nervous system and identifies a potential therapeutic target.

3 Points | 0 comments
items.title: Specialized astrocytes mediate glutamatergic gliotransmission in the CNS (www.nature.com)
items.summary: Specialized Astrocytes Mediate Glutamatergic Gliotransmission in the CNS

items.content_html:
Microsoft signs one of the biggest carbon removal deals to date with Heirloom Carbon, a startup that uses crushed rocks to absorb CO2 from the air. The deal involves capturing 315,000 metric tons of carbon over 10 years, equivalent to 75% of Microsoft's 2022 emissions. Heirloom's method involves heating limestone in an electric kiln to release CO2, then spreading the leftover calcium oxide on trays to absorb carbon from the air. The deal signifies confidence in Heirloom's approach and supports Microsoft's goal to become carbon negative by 2030. This type of long-term contract is similar to power purchase agreements in the renewable energy sector.

75 Points | 64 comments
items.title: Heirloom Carbon: Absorbing CO2 from the air using crushed rocks (heatmap.news)
items.summary: Microsoft Makes Major Investment in Carbon-Absorbing Rocks

items.content_html:
This empirical study examines the characteristics and current state of malicious code in the PyPI ecosystem. The researchers collected a dataset of 4,669 malicious package files and classified them into five categories based on their behavior. The study found that over 50% of the malicious code exhibited multiple malicious behaviors, with information stealing and command execution being common. The analysis revealed that 74.81% of the malicious packages successfully entered end-user projects through source code installation, posing significant security risks. Furthermore, many reported malicious packages persisted in PyPI mirror servers globally, even after being discovered. The study provides insights into the lifecycle of malicious code in the PyPI ecosystem and suggests mitigations to enhance the security of the Python open-source ecosystem.

33 Points | 21 comments
items.title: A Study of Malicious Code in PyPI Ecosystem (about.honywen.com)
items.summary: Understanding the State of Malicious Code in the PyPI Ecosystem

items.content_html:
Walking has been found to have a positive impact on thinking and creativity. When we walk, our heart pumps more blood and oxygen to the brain, leading to improved cognitive function. Walking also promotes new connections between brain cells and stimulates the growth of new neurons. The rhythm of walking creates a feedback loop with our mental state, allowing our thoughts to flow more freely. Walking in nature has been shown to be particularly beneficial for mental rejuvenation. Ultimately, walking and writing are similar activities that organize our thoughts and the world around us.

23 Points | 2 comments
items.title: Why walking helps us think (www.newyorker.com)
items.summary: The Connection Between Walking, Thinking, and Writing
